title: Protocol for measuring BRAF autoinhibition in live cells using a proximity-based NanoBRET assay
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Day 1: Seed cells
Timing: 30 min
      In this step, 293FT cells are seeded into wells of a 6-well tissue culture
      plate for transfection on Day 2. A single confluent 10 cm dish of 293FT
      cells will typically provide enough cells to plate 20 wells in 6-well
      plates.
    
        Detach 293FT cells from tissue culture dish (15 min).
        
Aspirate media from 10 cm dish.
Wash cells once with 5 mL PBS and aspirate.
Add 1 mL of trypsin-EDTA to cells.
            Incubate the 10 cm dish at 37°C for approximately 3–5 min or until
            cells begin to detach from the surface.
          
            Add 9 mL of DMEM growth media directly to the trypsin-EDTA/cell
            mixture.
          
            Pipette mixture up and down vigorously to generate a single-cell
            suspension.
          
        Count and seed cells (15 min).
        
            Add 15 μL of cell suspension to a 1.7 mL microfuge tube containing
            15 μL of trypan blue and mix.
          
            Pipette 10 μL of this mixture into duplicate cell counting chambers
            and determine cell number using an automated cell counter.
            Alternatively, a hemocytometer can be used for cell counting.
          
            Dilute cell suspension to 2 × 105 cells/mL and plate 2 mL
            of the diluted cell suspension (4 × 105 cells) into each
            well of the 6-well plates, seeding enough wells for the planned
            assays.
          
            Incubate plates at 37°C with 5% CO2 for 18 h, allowing
            the cells to recover and attach to the well surface.
          
Note: We recommend using 293FT cells that
      have been passaged no more than 20 times after purchase from the supplier.
      We have found that using cells at a higher passage number results in
      reduced transfection efficiency and greater variability in the NanoBRET
      readings.
    
Day 2: Transfect cells
Timing: 1 h
      In this step, the pCMV5-BRAFREG-Halo and pCMV5-Nano-BRAFCAT

NanoBRET expression constructs are transfected into cells.
    
        Transfect DNA complexes into cells.
        
Dilute NanoBRET plasmids to 5 ng/μL.
Dilute pcDNA3.1 empty vector to 100 ng/μL.
Pre-label sterile 1.7 mL tubes for each assay condition.
            Place 100 μL of serum-free Opti-MEM into each of the pre-labeled
            tubes.
          
            Add 20 ng of pCMV5-BRAFREG-Halo, 5 ng of
            pCMV5-Nano-BRAFCAT, and 200 ng of pcDNA3.1 empty vector
            directly into the Opti-MEM diluent.
          
            Add 2 μL of X-tremeGENE 9 to each sample and vortex briefly to mix.
          
            Pulse spin tubes in microfuge to remove any liquid that has
            accumulated in the lid.
          
            Incubate tubes for 15 min at 20–25°C to allow transfection complexes
            to form.
          
            Add transfection complexes dropwise to wells with attached cells.
          
            Incubate plates at 37°C with 5% CO2 for at least 16 h to
            allow expression of the exogenous proteins.
          
Critical: It is important that empty
      vector DNA (pcDNA3.1) be included in the transfection mix with the
      NanoBRET DNA constructs, as failure to add carrier DNA greatly reduces the
      transfection efficiency and results in inconsistent or weak NanoBRET
      signals. However, the amount of empty vector DNA can be reduced if other
      expression constructs are co-transfected. For example, if 100 ng of a
      plasmid encoding HA-tagged-KRAS G12V is co-transfected with the NanoBRET
      constructs then the amount of pcDNA3.1 can be reduced by 100 ng. In
      addition, given the sensitivity of the assay to expression levels,
      dilution accuracy and the use of high-purity plasmid DNAs, such as those
      obtained through commercially available plasmid maxiprep kits or by cesium
      chloride purification, are critical for both the transfection efficiency
      and reproducibility of the results.
    
Critical: Appropriate controls should
      be included when first performing the assay or when evaluating previously
      untested variants. Co-expression of an activated KRAS mutant, such as

G12V, is an appropriate external control for detecting a reduction in BRAF
      autoinhibitory interactions. As an internal control for reduced BRAF
      autoinhibition, BRAFREG-Halo construct containing the
      RASopathy-associated BRAF-CRD mutations T241P or Q257R can be used. It is
      expected that incorporation of these mutations will reduce the BRET ratio
      by approximately 50% when compared to the WT NanoBRET pair. Finally, a
      control condition consisting of untransfected cells should be included and
      is particularly helpful when examining the expression levels of the
      NanoBRET-tagged proteins by western blot analysis (Days 4 and 5).
    
Day 3: Replate cells
Timing: 1.5–2 h
      In this step, the cells are transferred to a 384-well white-walled tissue
      culture plate in either the presence or absence of the fluorescent
      NanoBRET HaloTag 618 ligand. In addition, to confirm that the expression
      levels of the BRET-tagged proteins are equivalent between samples, the
      remaining cells are replated into fresh 6-well plates for western blot
      analysis on Days 4 and 5.
    
        Assemble materials and prepare work area for cell replating (10 min).
        
            Label three sets of sterile 1.7 mL tubes (Set 1–3) and one set of
            sterile 15 mL conical tubes for each of the samples.
          
            Pre-warm trypsin-EDTA along with serum-free Opti-MEM (no phenol red)
            and Opti-MEM (no phenol red) containing 10% FBS in a 37°C water
            bath.
          
            Pre-cool a low-speed centrifuge with a swinging bucket rotor to 4°C.
          
            Gather the following items and pieces of equipment:
            
Multi-channel pipette and tips.
Reagent reservoirs.
384-well white-walled tissue culture plates.
6-well tissue culture plates.
Cell counting chambers.
Trypan blue stain.
        Collect and count cells (20 min).
        
            Aspirate growth media from 6-well tissue culture plates that contain
            cells.
          
Add 250 μL of trypsin-EDTA to each of these wells.
            Incubate plates at 37°C for 3–5 min or until cells begin to detach
            from the well surface.

Add 1 mL of 10% FBS Opti-MEM (no phenol red) to each well.
Pipette vigorously to generate a single-cell suspension.
Transfer cells to a 15 mL conical tube.
Add 10% FBS Opti-MEM to make a total volume of 2 mL.
            Mix cells and transfer 15 μL of the cell suspension to the 1.7 mL
            Set 1 tubes.
          
            Centrifuge the cell suspension in the 15 mL tubes at 200–300 × g
            for 5 min at 4°C.
          
            During centrifugation, add 15 μL of trypan blue stain to the cell
            suspension in the 1.7 mL Set 1 tubes.
          
            Count the cells as described above in Step 2 (a concentration of
            6–8 × 105 cells/mL is typical).
          
            After centrifugation, aspirate the media and flick the bottom of the
            tubes to loosen the cell pellets.
          
            Resuspend the cell pellets in serum-free Opti-MEM (no phenol red) to
            yield a final cell concentration of 2 × 105 cells/mL.
          
            Pipette vigorously to generate a homogeneous single-cell suspension.
          
Note: After detaching cells from the
      6-well tissue culture plates, cells are resuspended in Opti-MEM containing
      10% serum to neutralize the proteolytic activity of trypsin (Step 5d).
      However, in Step 5m, cell pellets are resuspended in serum-free Opti-MEM
      prior to replating, which is needed to quiesce the normal cell signaling
      pathways that can promote BRAF activation.
    
        Replate cells (1–1.5 h).
        
            Invert 15 mL tubes several times to ensure a homogeneous single cell
            suspension.
          
            Pipette 500 μL of the cell suspension into the sterile 1.7 mL Set 2
            and Set 3 tubes.
          
            Add 0.5 μL of the Halo618 ligand into each of the Set 2 samples (+
            ligand) and 0.5 μL of DMSO into each of the Set 3 samples (vehicle).
          
            For each condition, mix samples thoroughly and transfer the cells in

Set 2 (+ ligand) and Set 3 (vehicle) tubes to separate wells of a
            reagent reservoir.
          
            Using a multichannel pipette, plate 40 μL of the + ligand-containing
            cell suspension into quadruplicate wells of a 384-well plate and
            plate the vehicle (DMSO)-containing cell suspension in an identical
            manner.
          
            Transfer the remaining cell suspension in the 15 mL tubes into
            individual wells of fresh 6-well tissue culture plates for western
            blot analysis.
          
Incubate plates for 16 h at 37°C with 5% CO2.
Critical: To ensure that cells are
      accurately counted and seeded, the cell mixtures must be frequently mixed
      to maintain a homogenous suspension.
    
      Day 4: Read NanoBRET emissions and calculate the corrected BRET ratio
    
Timing: 30 min
      In this step, a furimazine-based nanoluciferase substrate (NanoGlo) is
      added to the cells, and the 460 nm (donor) and 618 nm (acceptor) emissions
      are recorded. From the recorded emissions, a corrected BRET ratio is
      determined.
    
        Add the NanoGlo substrate to cells in the 384-well plate, record the
        NanoBRET emissions, and calculate the corrected BRET ratio.
        
            Pre-warm serum-free Opti-MEM (no phenol red) to 37°C and allow the
            NanoGlo substrate to equilibrate to 20–25°C.
          
Dilute the NanoGlo substrate 1:100 in serum-free Opti-MEM.
Transfer the substrate mixture to a reagent reservoir.
            Prepare enough volume of the substrate mixture such that 10 μL of
            the mix can be added to each well of the 384 well plate that
            contains cells.
            
Note: We recommend preparing at
              least 10% extra volume to account for the volume lost when
              dispensing from a reagent reservoir.
            
            Using a repeat multichannel pipettor, add 10 μL of the substrate mix
            to each well of the 384 well plate that contains cells.
          
            Shake the plate on an orbital shaker for 1 min at approximately
            150 rpm.

Record the donor (460 nm) and acceptor (618 nm) emissions within
            10 min of substrate addition using a multi-label plate reader.

            for the vehicle and + ligand readings in milliBRET Units (mBU):

              (618 nm) and donor (460 nm) emissions for the interactions of
              Nano-BRAFCAT with WT-BRAFREG-Halo versus
              BRAFREG-Halo containing the RASopathy-associated T241P
              CRD mutation, previously shown to reduce BRAF autoinhibitory
              interactions by approximately 50%.1 To pool and compare
              results from multiple experiments, the corrected NanoBRET ratios
              can also be normalized to the WT NanoBRET pair (Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2]), and statistical significance can be calculated in a pairwise
              manner in GraphPad Prism using an unpaired Student’s t-test
              (two-tailed, assuming unequal variance).
            
Note: Inconsistent BRET ratios
              between replicate wells may indicate a poor cell transfection
              efficiency, which in turn can lead to low or varied expression of
              the BRET-tagged proteins. See

              solutions.

Days 4 & 5: Confirm expression levels
Timing: 6 h
      This step monitors the expression levels of the BRAFREG-Halo
      and Nano-BRAFCAT variants, as well as other proteins (such as
      activated KRAS) that might be co-expressed with the NanoBRET pair.

Lyse cells in the 6-well plates and normalize protein levels (1 h).
        
            Add protease and phosphatase inhibitors to NP40 lysis buffer.
            
Note: We typically prepare 200 μL
              of lysis buffer per sample.
            
Aspirate media from 6-well plates.
Wash cells once with 1 mL of ice-cold PBS and aspirate.
Add 125 μL of NP40 lysis buffer to each well of cells.
            Place the 6-well plates on a rocking platform at 4°C for 15 min.
          
During Step 8e, pre-cool a microcentrifuge to 4°C.
Label 2 sets of 1.7 mL tubes, placing Set 1 on ice.
Transfer lysates to Set 1 tubes.
            Spin Set 1 tubes in the pre-cooled microfuge for 10 min at the
            maximum speed of around 20,000 × g to clear the lysates of
            cellular debris.
          
            After spinning, place lysates on ice and determine the protein
            concentration of each sample using commercially available assays
            such as Bradford Assay (Bio-Rad) or BCA protein assay (Pierce).
          
            Transfer the appropriate amount of lysate supernatant (being careful
            not to disturb the pelleted debris) to the 1.7 mL Set 2 tubes,
            normalizing the protein content of the samples using NP40 lysis
            buffer to a give a final volume of 100 μL.
          
            Boil 5× protein sample buffer for 1 min and then add 25 μL to each
            sample.
          
            Boil samples for 5–6 min. Protein samples can now be stored at −80°C
            or separated by SDS-PAGE as described in Step 9a below.
          
        Western blot analysis (4 h on Day 4 and 2 h on Day 5).
        
            Run 25 μL of the protein samples on duplicate SDS-PAGE gels (2 h).
            
Note: We typically use Invitrogen
              Novex WedgeWell Tris-Glycine mini-protein gels, 1.0 mm thickness
              with a polyacrylamide concentration of 8% or 10%
            
Note: If co-expressing proteins of
              lower molecular weight, such as activated KRAS (21 kDa), then an

additional gel with a higher polyacrylamide concentration will be
              needed (e.g., 12% or 4%–20%).
            
            Transfer the separated proteins from the gels to nitrocellulose or
            PVDF membranes (1.5 h using a standard wet tank transfer system).
          
            Using a rocking platform, block the membranes for 30 min at 20–25°C
            in a solution of 3% BSA in PBS.
          
Remove the blocking solution,
            Rinse membranes once with TBS (1×) containing 0.2% Tween20 (TBST)
          
            Incubate the membranes for at least 16 h at 4°C with the following
            antibodies diluted 1:1000 in TBST.
            
Gel 1: Anti-Halo (mouse monoclonal antibody).
Gel 2: Anti-NanoLuc (mouse monoclonal antibody).
            The following day, wash the membranes three times in TBST for 5 min
            per wash.
          
            Incubate the membranes for 1 h at 20–25°C in anti-mouse HRP
            secondary antibody diluted 1:10,000 in TBST.
          
Wash membranes three times in TBST for 5 min per wash
            Visualize the signals using ECL reagents, X-ray film, and a film
            processor or other ECL-compatible imaging systems.
            
Note: If non-equivalent expression
              levels of the REG and/or CAT domain proteins are observed, refer
              to troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] for possible
              solutions.
            
Note: Due to the low ng quantities
              of transfected plasmids, longer exposures or more potent ECL
              reagents, such as Immobilon™ Western Chemiluminescent HRP
              Substrate (cat# WBKLS0500), may be required for visualizing the
              BRAFREG-Halo and Nano-BRAFCAT bands.
              Alternatively, other western blot detection systems can be used.
